chapters.summary: God creates the heavens, earth, and all life in six days, culminating with humanity made in His image to rule creation.
God forms Adam, plants Eden, creates Eve as his partner, and establishes the first marriage in perfect harmony.
The serpent tempts Eve and Adam; they disobey God, bringing sin, death, and separation, yet God promises redemption.
Cain murders Abel out of jealousy; sin spreads as Cain builds the first city and his descendants develop civilization.
Adam's genealogy spans 1,656 years to Noah; Enoch walks with God and is taken; Methuselah lives 969 years.
Humanity's wickedness grieves God; He chooses Noah to build an ark and preserve life through the coming flood.
Noah, his family, and animals enter the ark; God shuts them in as rain falls for 40 days, flooding the earth.
The flood waters recede; Noah sends out birds to test the land, then exits the ark and offers sacrifice to God.
God establishes a covenant with Noah, permits eating meat, institutes human government, and promises never to flood the earth again.
The table of nations: descendants of Noah's sons spread across the earth, establishing 70 distinct people groups.
Humanity rebels by building Babel; God confuses their language and scatters them, then calls Abraham to start over.
Jacob's descendants multiply in Egypt; new Pharaoh oppresses Israel with slavery and attempts genocide.
Moses is born, raised in Pharaoh's house, flees to Midian after killing an Egyptian; God hears Israel's cries.
God calls Moses from the burning bush, reveals His name YAHWEH, and commissions him to deliver Israel.
God gives Moses miraculous signs; Aaron becomes his spokesman; Moses returns to Egypt with God's message.
Moses and Aaron confront Pharaoh; he refuses and increases Israel's burdens; the people blame Moses.
God reassures Moses of His covenant promises and power; genealogy of Moses and Aaron's lineage.
Aaron's staff becomes a serpent; the first plague turns water to blood throughout Egypt.
Plagues of frogs, gnats, and flies demonstrate God's power; Pharaoh repeatedly hardens his heart.
Plagues on livestock, boils, and devastating hail with fire show God's sovereignty over Egypt.
Locusts devour Egypt and thick darkness covers the land; Pharaoh's final refusal before the ultimate plague.
God announces the death of every firstborn; Egyptians will give Israel silver and gold as they leave.
The Passover instituted; death of Egypt's firstborn; Israel's exodus begins after 430 years in Egypt.
Consecration of firstborn; God leads Israel by pillar of cloud and fire toward the wilderness.
Pharaoh pursues Israel to the Red Sea; God parts the waters and destroys Egypt's army.
Moses and Miriam lead victory songs; bitter water at Marah made sweet; God promises healing.
Israel complains about food; God provides manna and quail; Sabbath principle introduced with gathering rules.
Water from the rock at Massah; Amalekites attack Israel; Moses' raised hands ensure Joshua's victory.
Jethro visits Moses, worships God, and advises him to delegate judicial responsibilities to capable leaders.
Israel arrives at Sinai; God proposes covenant relationship; the people prepare to meet their holy God.
The Ten Commandments given; Israel fears God's presence and asks Moses to be their mediator.
Laws about Hebrew servants, violence, and property damage establish justice and social order.
Laws concerning theft, property damage, moral conduct, and social justice reflect God's character.
Justice in legal proceedings; festivals and Sabbaths; promises for conquest of the Promised Land.
Moses reads the covenant; people agree; Moses, Aaron, and elders see God; Moses ascends for forty days.
Instructions for the ark, table, and lampstand; God desires to dwell among His people.
Detailed plans for the tabernacle structure: curtains, frames, and the veil separating holy places.
The bronze altar for sacrifices and the courtyard design; God's dwelling place takes shape.
Aaron and sons consecrated as priests; detailed instructions for sacred garments reflecting God's glory.
Ordination ceremony for priests; daily sacrifices; God promises to dwell among Israel.
Altar of incense, census tax, bronze basin, anointing oil, and incense recipes for worship.
Bezalel and Oholiab chosen as craftsmen; Sabbath as covenant sign; Moses receives stone tablets.
Israel worships golden calf while Moses is on mountain; Moses intercedes; 3,000 die for idolatry.
God threatens to withdraw His presence; Moses pleads; God reveals His glory and character.
New tablets; God proclaims His name and attributes; covenant renewed; Moses' face shines with glory.
Sabbath emphasized; people give generously for tabernacle construction; hearts willing and stirred.
Skilled workers begin construction; people give so much they must be restrained from bringing more.
Bezalel crafts the ark, table, and lampstand according to God's detailed specifications.
Bronze altar, basin, and courtyard completed; inventory of materials shows faithful stewardship.
Priestly garments made exactly as commanded; all work inspected and blessed by Moses.
Tabernacle erected on first day of second year; God's glory fills His dwelling place among Israel.
God instructs Moses on the burnt offering, detailing how the Israelites should present cattle, sheep, goats, or birds as voluntary offerings to atone for sin and express devotion to the Lord.
The grain offering is established as a way to present flour, oil, and frankincense to God, with portions burned on the altar and the remainder given to the priests as their provision.

The peace offering is described as a voluntary sacrifice of cattle, sheep, or goats to express gratitude and fellowship with God, with specific portions burned and others shared between priests and worshipers.

Sin offerings are prescribed for unintentional sins, with different requirements for the high priest, the congregation, leaders, and common people, emphasizing the seriousness of sin and need for atonement.

Additional sin offerings and guilt offerings are detailed for specific situations including false testimony, touching unclean things, and rash oaths, along with provisions for those who cannot afford standard offerings.
God provides instructions to the priests about maintaining the altar fire and handling the burnt offering, grain offering, and sin offering, emphasizing the sacred nature of their duties.
Detailed regulations for the guilt offering and peace offering are given, including what portions belong to the priests and prohibitions against eating fat and blood.
Moses consecrates Aaron and his sons as priests through washing, clothing them in sacred garments, anointing with oil, and offering sacrifices, establishing the priesthood for Israel.
Aaron begins his priestly ministry by offering sacrifices for himself and the people, culminating in God's fire consuming the offerings and His glory appearing to all Israel.

Nadab and Abihu, Aaron's sons, are killed by God's fire for offering unauthorized incense, teaching the importance of approaching God according to His prescribed ways and maintaining priestly holiness.
God establishes dietary laws distinguishing between clean and unclean animals, emphasizing Israel's call to holiness and separation from other nations through their eating practices.
Laws concerning purification after childbirth are given, requiring different periods of ceremonial uncleanness and specific offerings for male and female children.
Detailed instructions for diagnosing and managing skin diseases and mildew are provided, with priests serving as health inspectors to determine ceremonial cleanness or uncleanness.
The cleansing ritual for those healed of skin diseases is prescribed, involving birds, cedar wood, scarlet yarn, hyssop, and various offerings to restore them to community fellowship.
Laws regarding bodily discharges are established, detailing purification requirements for both men and women to maintain ceremonial cleanness in the camp.
The Day of Atonement is instituted as an annual ceremony where the high priest enters the Most Holy Place to make atonement for himself, the priesthood, and all Israel's sins.
Regulations about sacrifices and eating meat are given, requiring all sacrifices to be brought to the tabernacle and prohibiting the consumption of blood, which contains life and makes atonement.
God prohibits various sexual practices including incest, adultery, homosexuality, and bestiality, calling Israel to moral purity distinct from Egyptian and Canaanite customs.
The holiness code begins with calls to reverence parents, keep the Sabbath, avoid idolatry, and love one's neighbor as oneself, establishing foundational principles for holy living.
Penalties for serious sins are prescribed, including death for child sacrifice, adultery, homosexuality, and consulting mediums, emphasizing God's call for Israel to be holy and separate.

Special holiness requirements for priests are established, including restrictions on mourning practices, marriage, and physical defects, reflecting their sacred role as mediators between God and people.
Additional priestly regulations ensure ceremonial purity when handling sacred offerings and establish standards for acceptable sacrificial animals, maintaining the integrity of worship.
God establishes Israel's sacred calendar with detailed instructions for observing the Sabbath, Passover, Feast of Weeks, Feast of Trumpets, Day of Atonement, and Feast of Tabernacles.
Instructions for maintaining the lampstand and bread of the Presence are given, followed by the punishment of a blasphemer and the establishment of the principle of proportional justice.
The sabbatical year and Year of Jubilee are instituted to provide rest for the land, release for Hebrew slaves, and redemption of property, emphasizing God's ownership of all things.
God promises blessings for obedience including rain, abundant harvests, peace, and His presence, while warning of escalating curses for disobedience including exile from the land.

Laws concerning vows and dedicated offerings are established, including the redemption values for people, animals, houses, and fields dedicated to the Lord, concluding Leviticus with principles of sacred commitment.
Moses conducts the first census of Israel's fighting men (excluding Levites), numbering over 600,000 males aged twenty and above from the twelve tribes, as commanded by God at Mount Sinai.
God establishes the arrangement of the twelve tribes around the tabernacle during their wilderness encampments, with specific positioning and marching order under their respective banners.
The Levites are set apart for tabernacle service in place of Israel's firstborn, with Aaron's sons appointed as priests and the Levitical clans assigned specific duties for the sacred tent.
Detailed instructions are given for the Kohathites, Gershonites, and Merarites regarding their specific responsibilities in transporting and caring for the tabernacle and its holy objects.
Laws are established for maintaining camp purity through quarantine of the unclean, restitution for wrongs, and the ritual test for suspected adultery (the bitter water ordeal).
God provides regulations for the Nazirite vow of separation and gives Aaron the priestly blessing formula to pronounce over the Israelites.
The twelve tribal leaders present identical offerings for the dedication of the altar over twelve days, demonstrating unity and God's acceptance of their worship.
Aaron lights the seven lamps of the lampstand, and the Levites are ceremonially purified and set apart for their service in the tabernacle on behalf of all Israel.
Israel celebrates the first Passover in the wilderness, with provisions made for those ceremonially unclean, while the cloud of God's presence guides their movements.
Silver trumpets are made for assemblies and signaling marches, and Israel begins their journey from Sinai toward the Promised Land in organized formation.
The people complain about hardships and demand meat instead of manna, leading to God's anger, the provision of quail, and a plague as judgment for their ingratitude.
Miriam and Aaron challenge Moses' authority and unique relationship with God, resulting in Miriam being struck with leprosy until Moses intercedes for her healing.
Twelve spies are sent to scout the Promised Land and return with evidence of its abundance, but ten give a fearful report while only Joshua and Caleb encourage faith in God's promises.
Israel rebels against entering the Promised Land due to fear, prompting God's judgment that the entire generation (except Joshua and Caleb) will die in the wilderness over forty years.

God provides laws for offerings in the future land, establishes procedures for unintentional sins, and executes a man for deliberate Sabbath violation, while instituting tassels as reminders of God's commands.
Korah, Dathan, and Abiram lead a rebellion against Moses and Aaron's authority, resulting in the earth swallowing the rebels and fire consuming 250 incense offerers.
To confirm Aaron's unique priestly calling, God causes Aaron's staff to miraculously bud, blossom, and produce almonds among the twelve tribal staffs.
God establishes the permanent responsibilities and provisions for the priests and Levites, including their duties, portions of offerings, and the tithe system for their sustenance.
The ritual of the red heifer is instituted to provide ceremonial purification from defilement caused by contact with the dead, essential for maintaining covenant relationship with God.
Miriam dies, the people complain about lack of water, and Moses and Aaron sin by striking the rock instead of speaking to it, resulting in their exclusion from the Promised Land.
Israel defeats the Canaanites at Hormah, complains about the journey leading to fiery serpents as judgment, finds healing through the bronze serpent, and conquers the Amorite kings Sihon and Og.
Balak, king of Moab, hires the prophet Balaam to curse Israel, but God intervenes through a speaking donkey and commands Balaam to bless Israel instead.
Despite Balak's repeated attempts and offerings, Balaam pronounces blessings on Israel instead of curses, declaring God's faithfulness to His covenant people.
Balaam delivers his final oracles blessing Israel and prophesying their future dominance, including the messianic prophecy of the star and scepter from Jacob.
Israel falls into idolatry and immorality with Moabite women at Baal-Peor, leading to a plague that is stopped only when Phinehas executes an Israelite man and Midianite woman in zealous obedience.
A second census is conducted after the plague, showing God's faithfulness in maintaining Israel's numbers despite judgment, and establishing inheritance rights for the new generation entering Canaan.
The daughters of Zelophehad successfully petition for inheritance rights when there are no male heirs, and Moses is shown the Promised Land before God appoints Joshua as his successor.
God establishes the regular schedule of daily, weekly, and monthly offerings that Israel must maintain to worship Him properly in the land.
Detailed instructions are given for the special offerings required during the seventh month festivals: the Feast of Trumpets, Day of Atonement, and Feast of Tabernacles.
Laws regarding vows are established, particularly addressing the authority of fathers and husbands to confirm or nullify vows made by daughters and wives under their care.
God commands Israel to take vengeance on the Midianites for leading them into sin at Baal-Peor, resulting in complete victory and the distribution of spoils according to divine law.
The tribes of Reuben, Gad, and half of Manasseh request to settle east of the Jordan River, which Moses grants on condition they help conquer the Promised Land first.
Moses records the complete itinerary of Israel's forty-year wilderness journey from Egypt to the plains of Moab, demonstrating God's faithful guidance throughout their wanderings.
God defines the precise boundaries of the Promised Land that Israel will inherit and appoints leaders from each tribe to oversee the distribution of the territory.
The Levites are assigned forty-eight cities throughout Israel including six cities of refuge where those guilty of accidental manslaughter can find protection from vengeful relatives.
The final law addresses marriage restrictions for female heirs to ensure that tribal inheritances remain within their designated tribes, concluding the wilderness legislation at the plains of Moab.

Moses begins his farewell address by recounting Israel's journey from Mount Horeb, including the appointment of judges and the command to enter the Promised Land that their fathers' generation refused to obey.
Moses recounts Israel's wilderness wanderings and God's instructions to avoid conflict with the descendants of Esau and Lot while conquering the Amorite kingdoms east of the Jordan.

Moses describes the conquest of King Og of Bashan and the distribution of the Transjordan territory to Reuben, Gad, and half the tribe of Manasseh, while being reminded that he himself cannot enter the Promised Land.
Moses urges Israel to obey God's laws and statutes, warning against idolatry and emphasizing that their obedience will demonstrate God's wisdom to the nations and ensure their prosperity in the land.
Moses restates the Ten Commandments given at Mount Horeb and recalls how the people requested that Moses serve as mediator between them and God due to their fear of God's awesome presence.

Moses delivers the great commandment to love the Lord with all their heart, soul, and strength, instructing parents to teach God's laws diligently to their children and to remember God's faithfulness when they prosper in the land.

Moses commands Israel to completely destroy the Canaanite nations and their idols, reminding them that they are God's chosen people not because of their greatness but because of God's love and faithfulness to His promises.

Moses warns Israel to remember the Lord when they prosper in the Promised Land, recalling how God humbled them in the wilderness with manna to teach them that man lives by every word from God's mouth.

Moses reminds Israel that their conquest of the land is not due to their righteousness but because of the wickedness of the nations and God's faithfulness to His promises, recounting the golden calf incident as evidence of their rebellion.

Moses recounts the making of the second set of stone tablets, the construction of the ark, and emphasizes that God desires circumcised hearts that fear Him, serve Him, and care for the vulnerable in society.

Moses calls Israel to love and obey the Lord, promising blessings for obedience and curses for disobedience, and instructs them to teach God's words to their children and bind them as signs upon themselves.

Moses establishes laws for worship in the Promised Land, commanding the destruction of pagan worship sites and designating one central place where God will choose to put His name for sacrifices and offerings.
Moses warns against false prophets and idolatrous family members or cities, commanding that those who lead Israel away from the Lord must be put to death to purge evil from among them.

Moses reaffirms Israel's identity as God's holy people through dietary laws, distinguishing clean and unclean animals, and establishes the principle of tithing to support worship and care for the needy.
Moses institutes the sabbatical year for debt release and freeing Hebrew servants, commanding generous treatment of the poor and proper procedures for those who choose permanent servitude.

Moses establishes the three major annual festivals—Passover, Feast of Weeks, and Feast of Tabernacles—and provides instructions for appointing judges who will administer justice fairly without partiality or bribes.

Moses gives laws concerning proper sacrifices, procedures for dealing with idolatry, the role of priests and Levites in difficult legal cases, and regulations for future kings who must be guided by God's law.

Moses defines the inheritance and duties of the Levitical priests, warns against occult practices of the nations, and promises that God will raise up a prophet like Moses to speak His words to the people.

Moses establishes cities of refuge for accidental killers and sets procedures for witnesses in legal cases, emphasizing the principle of justice and the requirement of multiple witnesses for serious accusations.

Moses provides laws for warfare, including encouragement for soldiers, exemptions from military service, procedures for besieging cities, and instructions for dealing with both distant and nearby enemies.

Moses addresses various civil laws including procedures for unsolved murders, treatment of captive women, inheritance rights of firstborn sons, and dealing with rebellious children and executed criminals.

Moses establishes laws for social responsibility and moral purity, covering topics from returning lost property and helping neighbors to regulations concerning marriage, sexual conduct, and proper gender distinctions.

Moses defines who may enter the assembly of the Lord, establishes laws for maintaining cleanliness in military camps, and provides regulations for escaped slaves, temple prostitution, and lending practices.
Moses provides laws concerning divorce and remarriage, fair treatment of workers and debtors, justice for the vulnerable, and proper procedures for punishment while maintaining human dignity.

Moses establishes limits on corporal punishment, laws for levirate marriage to preserve family lines, honest business practices with accurate weights and measures, and the command to destroy the Amalekites.
Moses prescribes rituals for offering firstfruits and tithes that include reciting God's mighty acts in Israel's history, concluding with mutual covenant declarations between God and His people.

Moses, with the elders and priests, commands Israel to set up stones inscribed with the law on Mount Ebal and prescribes a covenant renewal ceremony with blessings and curses proclaimed from mounts Gerizim and Ebal.

Moses presents the covenant's blessings for obedience and extensive curses for disobedience, describing in vivid detail the prosperity that comes from following God and the devastating consequences of rebellion.

Moses calls Israel to renew their covenant with the Lord, warning that future generations will witness God's judgment if they forsake the covenant, while acknowledging that some things belong to God's secret counsel.

Moses prophesies Israel's future exile and restoration, calling them to choose life by loving and obeying the Lord, emphasizing that God's commandment is not too difficult or distant but near to their hearts.

Moses transfers leadership to Joshua, commands the regular public reading of the law, and receives God's prediction that Israel will rebel after his death, prompting the writing of a song as a witness against them.
Moses recites his song that serves as a prophetic witness, recounting God's faithfulness to unfaithful Israel and declaring that God will ultimately vindicate His people and judge their enemies.

Moses delivers his final blessing upon the twelve tribes of Israel, celebrating God as their eternal refuge and strength while prophesying each tribe's distinctive future and calling Israel blessed among nations.
Moses views the Promised Land from Mount Nebo before dying at age 120 with undiminished strength, and the narrative concludes by affirming that no prophet like Moses has since arisen in Israel.
God commands Joshua to lead Israel into the Promised Land, promising His presence and success if they courageously obey His law. Joshua prepares the people for crossing the Jordan River into Canaan.

Joshua sends two spies to scout Jericho, where Rahab the prostitute hides them and professes faith in Israel's God. In return for her protection, the spies promise to spare her and her family when Israel conquers the city.

The Israelites cross the Jordan River on dry ground as God miraculously stops the flowing water when the priests carrying the ark step into it. This miracle demonstrates God's power and establishes Joshua's leadership before all Israel.

Twelve stones are taken from the Jordan riverbed to create a memorial at Gilgal, serving as a lasting testimony to God's mighty work for future generations. The crossing is completed and the people camp at Gilgal, their first base in the Promised Land.

The Israelite men are circumcised at Gilgal, and the people celebrate Passover in the Promised Land for the first time. The manna ceases as they begin eating the produce of Canaan, and Joshua encounters the commander of the Lord's army.

Jericho falls after Israel marches around the city for seven days according to God's specific instructions, with the walls collapsing when they shout and blow trumpets. Rahab and her family are spared, but the city is devoted to destruction except for items going to God's treasury.

Israel suffers defeat at Ai because Achan secretly took devoted items from Jericho, violating God's command. After Achan and his family are executed for their sin, God's anger is turned away from Israel.

Israel successfully conquers Ai using a divinely-given battle strategy involving an ambush, demonstrating that victory comes through obedience to God. Joshua builds an altar on Mount Ebal and publicly reads the entire law to all Israel.

The Gibeonites deceive Israel into making a peace treaty by pretending to be from a distant land, violating God's command to destroy all Canaanites. Though bound by their oath, Israel makes the Gibeonites servants, showing the consequences of not seeking God's counsel.

Joshua leads Israel to victory over a coalition of five Amorite kings who attacked Gibeon, with God fighting for Israel by sending hailstones and making the sun stand still. The southern region of Canaan is conquered as God delivers enemy after enemy into Israel's hands.

Joshua defeats a northern coalition led by Jabin of Hazor, completing the conquest of Canaan's major population centers. The chapter emphasizes that Joshua carried out all of Moses' commands and that the land had rest from war.

A comprehensive list records all the kings defeated by Moses east of the Jordan and by Joshua west of the Jordan. This chapter serves as a testimony to God's faithfulness in giving Israel victory over 31 kings and their territories.

Though much land remains to be possessed, God instructs Joshua to begin dividing the inheritance among the nine and a half tribes. The chapter details the territory of Reuben, Gad, and half of Manasseh who received their inheritance east of the Jordan.

The inheritance process begins west of the Jordan, with Caleb receiving Hebron as his personal inheritance due to his faithful service and wholehearted devotion to God. At 85 years old, Caleb demonstrates continued strength and faith in claiming his promised territory.

The detailed boundaries and cities of Judah's tribal inheritance are established, showing God's faithfulness in fulfilling His promises to the patriarchs. Caleb successfully drives out the Anakim from his inheritance, while the Jebusites remain in Jerusalem.

The inheritance boundaries for the tribe of Ephraim are described, though they fail to completely drive out the Canaanites from their territory. This partial obedience foreshadows future problems and compromises in Israel's faithfulness to God.

The other half of Manasseh receives their inheritance, including special provisions for Zelophehad's daughters who inherit land according to Moses' earlier ruling. The tribe complains about their allotment size, but Joshua challenges them to clear the forested hill country.

The remaining seven tribes receive their inheritances after Joshua rebukes their delay in claiming what God has given them. The tabernacle is set up at Shiloh, and surveyors map out the remaining land for division by lot.

The final six tribes (Simeon, Zebulun, Issachar, Asher, Naphtali, and Dan) receive their territorial inheritances through the casting of lots. Joshua himself receives the city of Timnath-serah as his personal inheritance, completing the land distribution process.

Six cities of refuge are established where those who accidentally kill someone can flee for protection from the avenger of blood. This provision demonstrates God's justice and mercy, providing due process while protecting both the innocent and the rights of victims' families.

The Levites receive 48 cities scattered throughout all the tribal territories, fulfilling God's promise to provide for those who serve Him in the tabernacle. The chapter concludes by affirming that God kept every promise He made to Israel regarding the land.

The eastern tribes (Reuben, Gad, and half of Manasseh) return home after faithfully serving in the conquest, but build an altar that nearly causes civil war. The crisis is resolved when they explain the altar is a witness to their faithfulness, not for forbidden worship.

In his first farewell address, an aged Joshua warns Israel to remain faithful to God and continue driving out the remaining Canaanites. He emphasizes that obedience brings blessing while disobedience will result in losing the Promised Land.

Joshua's final address recounts God's faithfulness throughout Israel's history and challenges the people to choose whom they will serve. Israel covenant renewally commits to serve the Lord alone, and Joshua dies at 110 years old, having faithfully completed his calling.
After Joshua’s death, Israel continues to fight remaining Canaanites. Judah leads, aided by Simeon. Some tribes fail to fully drive out inhabitants.
An angel rebukes Israel for disobedience. After Joshua’s generation dies, Israel falls into idolatry. God raises judges to deliver them, but the cycle of sin continues.
God leaves nations to test Israel. Othniel delivers them from Cushan-Rishathaim. Ehud kills Eglon of Moab, bringing peace. Shamgar strikes down 600 Philistines.
Deborah, a prophetess, leads Israel with Barak. God grants victory over Sisera’s army; Jael kills Sisera by driving a tent peg through his head.
The song of Deborah and Barak celebrates God’s victory over Canaan and Jael’s courage. The land has peace for 40 years.
Israel oppressed by Midian. God calls Gideon, who doubts and asks for signs. Gideon destroys Baal’s altar and gathers an army.
God reduces Gideon’s army to 300 to show His power. With trumpets, jars, and torches, they rout Midian’s vast army.
Gideon pursues and defeats Midian’s kings. Israel asks him to rule, but he refuses. He makes an ephod that becomes a snare to Israel.
Abimelek, Gideon’s son, seizes power by killing his brothers. His rule brings strife; he dies after a woman drops a millstone on his head.
Tola and Jair judge Israel. Later, Israel turns to idols, and God delivers them to Ammon. They cry for mercy, and He relents.
Jephthah, an outcast, is chosen to fight Ammon. He vows to sacrifice whatever first comes from his house. Victory comes, but his daughter is tragically offered.
Ephraim quarrels with Jephthah; thousands die. Jephthah judges six years. Ibzan, Elon, and Abdon serve as judges afterward.
Israel again sins. An angel tells Manoah’s wife she’ll bear Samson, set apart as a Nazirite from birth.
Samson desires a Philistine wife. He kills a lion and later finds honey in its carcass. He poses a riddle at his wedding feast.
Samson burns Philistine fields with foxes, kills many with a donkey’s jawbone after betrayal, and judges Israel for 20 years.
Samson loves Delilah, who betrays him. His hair is cut, he’s captured and blinded. He dies pulling down a Philistine temple, killing many.
Micah makes idols and hires a Levite as his priest, revealing Israel’s religious corruption.
The tribe of Dan steals Micah’s idols and priest, conquers Laish, and sets up idolatry.
A Levite’s concubine is abused and killed in Gibeah. He dismembers her body to summon Israel against such evil.
Israel unites against Benjamin for the atrocity in Gibeah. After heavy losses, Israel defeats Benjamin with God’s help.
Israel grieves Benjamin’s near destruction. Wives are found for the survivors through unconventional means. The book ends: “Everyone did what was right in his own eyes.”

Naomi’s family moves to Moab due to famine. Her husband and sons die, leaving Naomi and her daughters-in-law. Ruth clings to Naomi, pledging loyalty to her and to God. They return to Bethlehem at harvest time.
Ruth gleans in the fields of Boaz, a relative of Naomi. Boaz shows kindness and protection, providing food and favor. Naomi recognizes God’s providence and Boaz as a potential redeemer.
Naomi instructs Ruth to approach Boaz at the threshing floor. Ruth requests his protection as kinsman-redeemer. Boaz blesses her, promises to act, but mentions a nearer relative has first right.

Boaz redeems Ruth by negotiating with the nearer kinsman at the city gate. He marries Ruth, and they bear Obed, grandfather of King David. The story highlights God’s providence and Ruth’s place in the messianic line.
Hannah, barren and mocked, prays for a son and vows to dedicate him to the Lord. God grants Samuel, whom she presents to serve at Shiloh.
Hannah prays a song of praise. Eli’s sons, Hophni and Phinehas, are corrupt. A man of God foretells judgment on Eli’s household.
God calls young Samuel at night. Eli instructs him to answer. Samuel hears God’s word of judgment on Eli’s house and becomes recognized as a prophet.
Israel is defeated by the Philistines. The ark of God is captured. Eli’s sons die in battle, and Eli falls dead upon hearing the news.
The ark in Philistine territory brings plagues and humiliation to their god Dagon. The Philistines suffer tumors and panic.
The Philistines return the ark with guilt offerings. The people of Beth Shemesh rejoice but some die for irreverence toward the ark.
Samuel calls Israel to repent. At Mizpah, God thunders against the Philistines, granting victory. Samuel judges Israel faithfully.
Israel demands a king. Samuel warns of the burdens a king will impose, but the people insist. God grants their request.
Saul, searching for lost donkeys, meets Samuel. God reveals Saul as His choice for king. Samuel anoints Saul privately.
Samuel presents Saul to Israel. God’s Spirit comes upon Saul. Some accept him, others despise him.
Saul rallies Israel to defeat the Ammonites threatening Jabesh-gilead. The people affirm Saul as king with rejoicing.
Samuel gives a farewell speech, recounting God’s faithfulness. He warns Israel to obey God under their king, and prays as thunder confirms his words.
Saul leads Israel against the Philistines but disobeys by offering sacrifice himself. Samuel rebukes him and foretells loss of his dynasty.
Jonathan attacks a Philistine outpost, sparking victory. Saul makes a rash oath restricting food, causing trouble for Israel.
Saul spares King Agag and the best animals against God’s command. Samuel rebukes him: “To obey is better than sacrifice.” God rejects Saul as king.
God sends Samuel to Bethlehem to anoint David, son of Jesse. The Spirit comes on David. An evil spirit torments Saul; David plays the harp to soothe him.
David defeats Goliath with a sling and stone, declaring God’s power. Israel routs the Philistines. David becomes a hero.
David befriends Jonathan. Saul grows jealous of David’s success and plots against him. David prospers despite Saul’s hostility.
Saul orders David killed, but Jonathan intercedes. Saul again tries to kill David, who flees. God’s Spirit restrains Saul’s men and Saul himself.
Jonathan tests Saul’s intentions at a feast. Realizing Saul wants David dead, Jonathan warns David. The two make a covenant of friendship.
David flees to Nob, receives holy bread and Goliath’s sword. He escapes to Gath, feigns madness before King Achish.
Saul kills the priests of Nob for aiding David, except Abiathar who escapes. David gathers outcasts to himself as followers.
David rescues Keilah from the Philistines but flees from Saul’s pursuit. Jonathan encourages him. Saul nearly captures David but withdraws to fight Philistines.
David spares Saul in a cave, refusing to kill God’s anointed. He shows Saul the evidence, and Saul weeps, acknowledging David’s righteousness.
David seeks provisions from Nabal, who insults him. Abigail intercedes wisely, preventing bloodshed. God strikes Nabal dead; David marries Abigail.
David again spares Saul, taking his spear and water jug. He rebukes Saul, who admits his sin. David remains steadfast in not harming the king.
David flees to Philistine territory, living under King Achish in Ziklag. He raids enemies while deceiving Achish.
Saul, desperate before battle, consults the medium of Endor. Samuel’s spirit appears, foretelling Saul’s defeat and death.
Philistine leaders distrust David and send him away from their army. He returns to Ziklag.
Amalekites raid Ziklag, capturing families. David strengthens himself in God, pursues, and rescues all. Spoils are shared equally among his men.
Israel is defeated at Mount Gilboa. Saul’s sons, including Jonathan, are killed. Saul falls on his sword. The Philistines desecrate their bodies, but men of Jabesh-gilead recover them.
A man reports Saul’s death to David, claiming to have killed him. David mourns Saul and Jonathan with a lament over their bravery and love.
David is anointed king over Judah. Saul’s son Ish-bosheth becomes king over Israel. Abner and Joab’s men clash; Asahel is killed by Abner.
Abner defects to David after a quarrel with Ish-bosheth. Joab treacherously kills Abner in revenge. David laments Abner’s death.
Ish-bosheth is assassinated by two men, who bring his head to David. David executes them for murder and honors Ish-bosheth.
David is anointed king over all Israel. He captures Jerusalem and makes it his capital. God grants victory over the Philistines.
David brings the ark to Jerusalem. Uzzah dies for touching it. Later, with proper reverence, David dances before the ark. Michal despises him.
God makes a covenant with David, promising an eternal dynasty. David responds with a prayer of humble gratitude.
David defeats surrounding nations and reigns with justice. He dedicates captured treasures to the Lord and establishes officials.
David shows kindness to Mephibosheth, Jonathan’s crippled son, granting him Saul’s land and a permanent place at his table.
The Ammonites hire Aramean allies against Israel. David’s army, led by Joab, defeats them. The Arameans withdraw support for Ammon.
David commits adultery with Bathsheba and arranges Uriah’s death. Bathsheba becomes David’s wife, but God is displeased.
Nathan confronts David with a parable. David repents, but God announces consequences. Their first child dies; Solomon is later born.
Amnon rapes his sister Tamar. Absalom, Tamar’s brother, kills Amnon in revenge and flees into exile.
Joab arranges for Absalom’s return to Jerusalem. David allows him back but does not see him for two years.
Absalom wins the people’s favor and declares himself king at Hebron. David flees Jerusalem with his followers.
Ziba deceives David about Mephibosheth. Shimei curses David. Absalom enters Jerusalem and, on Ahithophel’s advice, sleeps with David’s concubines.
Ahithophel advises immediate pursuit, but Hushai counsels delay, saving David. Ahithophel, seeing his advice rejected, commits suicide.
David’s army defeats Absalom’s forces. Absalom is caught in a tree and killed by Joab. David mourns deeply for his son.
David returns to Jerusalem amid disputes. He shows mercy to Shimei and Mephibosheth, honors Barzillai, and faces division between Judah and Israel.
Sheba leads a revolt against David. Joab kills Amasa and besieges Abel Beth Maacah. A wise woman negotiates Sheba’s execution, ending the revolt.
Famine comes due to Saul’s past sin against the Gibeonites. Seven of Saul’s descendants are executed. David’s warriors defeat Philistine giants.
David sings a psalm of praise for God’s deliverance and faithfulness throughout his reign.
David’s last words exalt God’s covenant. The mighty men’s exploits are recounted, honoring their loyalty and bravery.
David orders a census, bringing guilt on Israel. God offers three judgments; David chooses plague. David builds an altar on Araunah’s threshing floor, where the plague stops.
David is old and frail. Adonijah exalts himself as king, but Nathan and Bathsheba secure Solomon’s coronation by David’s command.
David gives Solomon final instructions to be faithful and deal with adversaries. Solomon establishes his reign by executing Adonijah, Joab, and Shimei, and affirming loyal allies.
Solomon asks God for wisdom in a dream at Gibeon. God grants him wisdom and wealth. Solomon demonstrates discernment by judging between two women over a baby.
Solomon’s officials and governors are listed. Israel prospers under his reign, and Solomon’s wisdom becomes renowned throughout the world.
Solomon makes a treaty with Hiram of Tyre to supply cedar and laborers for building the temple. Preparations for construction begin.
Solomon builds the temple with precise detail, completing it in seven years. God promises His presence if Israel obeys His commands.
Solomon builds his palace and the Hall of Justice. Huram crafts bronze furnishings for the temple, including pillars, basins, and utensils.
The ark is brought into the temple. God’s glory fills the house. Solomon prays a dedicatory prayer, asking God to hear prayers directed toward this temple.
God reaffirms His covenant with Solomon. Solomon’s building projects expand, including cities and trade. Hiram receives towns from Solomon.
The Queen of Sheba visits Solomon, marvels at his wisdom, and praises God. Solomon’s wealth and splendor surpass all kings.
Solomon’s many foreign wives turn his heart to idolatry. God raises adversaries, including Jeroboam. God announces the kingdom will be torn from Solomon’s son.
Rehoboam becomes king. He rejects wise counsel and increases burdens, causing ten tribes to rebel and follow Jeroboam. Jeroboam establishes idolatrous worship in Bethel and Dan.
A man of God prophesies against Jeroboam’s altar. Jeroboam’s hand shrivels but is restored. The prophet disobeys God’s command and is killed by a lion.
Jeroboam’s son becomes sick. A prophet foretells judgment on Jeroboam’s house. Judah also turns to idolatry under Rehoboam. Rehoboam faces Egyptian invasion.
Abijam and Asa reign over Judah. Asa does what is right, removing idols, but does not eliminate high places. Nadab and Baasha reign in Israel; Baasha destroys Jeroboam’s house.
Baasha’s dynasty is condemned. Elah, Zimri, Omri, and Ahab follow as kings of Israel. Ahab marries Jezebel and promotes Baal worship, provoking God’s anger.
Elijah announces drought in Israel. God provides for him by ravens and a widow. Elijah raises the widow’s son from the dead, showing God’s power.
Elijah confronts Ahab and challenges Baal’s prophets on Mount Carmel. God answers Elijah with fire, proving He is God. The drought ends with Elijah’s prayer.
Elijah flees Jezebel in fear. God reveals Himself in a gentle whisper at Mount Horeb. Elijah is reassured and called to anoint successors, including Elisha.
Ahab defeats Ben-hadad of Aram with God’s help, but spares him against God’s command. A prophet condemns Ahab for letting him go.
Ahab covets Naboth’s vineyard. Jezebel arranges Naboth’s death. Elijah confronts Ahab, pronouncing doom on his house. Ahab humbles himself, delaying judgment.
Micaiah prophesies Ahab’s death despite pressure to agree with false prophets. Ahab disguises himself in battle but is killed. Jehoshaphat reigns in Judah; Ahaziah in Israel.
King Ahaziah seeks Baal-zebub’s counsel after an injury. Elijah confronts messengers, calls down fire on captains, and foretells Ahaziah’s death.
Elijah is taken up to heaven in a whirlwind. Elisha inherits his mantle, parts the Jordan, and performs miracles, including healing water and cursing mocking youths.
Jehoram of Israel, Jehoshaphat, and Edom ally against Moab. Elisha prophesies victory; God miraculously provides water and defeats Moab.
Elisha performs miracles: multiplying oil for a widow, raising a Shunammite’s son, purifying poisoned stew, and feeding a hundred men with limited bread.
Naaman, a Syrian commander, is healed of leprosy after washing in the Jordan. Gehazi, Elisha’s servant, lies for profit and is struck with leprosy.
Elisha makes an iron axe head float. He reveals Aramean ambushes. God blinds the enemy army. During siege, famine grips Samaria.
Elisha prophesies relief from famine. Four lepers discover the Arameans have fled. Samaria plunders the abandoned camp, fulfilling prophecy.
Elisha foretells seven years of famine and Hazael’s rise in Syria. Jehoram and Ahaziah reign in Judah, walking in wickedness like Ahab’s house.
Elisha’s prophet anoints Jehu king. Jehu kills Joram, Ahaziah, Jezebel, and Ahab’s household, fulfilling prophecy.
Jehu massacres Ahab’s seventy sons and destroys Baal worship in Israel, but does not turn from Jeroboam’s sins. God promises his dynasty four generations.
Athaliah seizes power in Judah but is overthrown by Jehoiada the priest, who crowns Joash as king. Athaliah is executed, and covenant worship is restored.
Joash repairs the temple but later compromises. He pays tribute to Hazael of Syria. His officials assassinate him, and Amaziah reigns.
Jehoahaz and Jehoash reign in Israel. They sin but occasionally seek God’s help. Elisha dies, leaving a legacy of miracles, including a resurrection.
Amaziah reigns in Judah, defeating Edom but losing to Israel. Jeroboam II reigns in Israel, expanding territory. Both walk in sin.
Multiple kings reign in Israel—Zechariah, Shallum, Menahem, Pekahiah, Pekah—marked by instability and assassination. In Judah, Azariah (Uzziah) prospers but is struck with leprosy.
Ahaz reigns in Judah, practicing idolatry and appealing to Assyria for help against Syria and Israel. He alters temple worship to please Assyria.
Hoshea, last king of Israel, rebels against Assyria. Samaria falls, and Israel is exiled. The cause: persistent idolatry and disobedience to God’s covenant.
Hezekiah reigns in Judah, reforms worship, and trusts God. Assyria invades; Rabshakeh mocks God. Hezekiah resists and seeks God’s help.
Hezekiah prays. Isaiah prophesies Assyria’s fall. That night, God’s angel strikes down 185,000 Assyrians. Sennacherib retreats and is killed by his sons.

Hezekiah falls ill but prays; God heals him, adding 15 years. The shadow on the sundial moves backward as a sign. Hezekiah shows envoys his treasures, prompting Isaiah’s warning of future Babylonian exile.
Manasseh reigns wickedly, filling Jerusalem with idolatry and bloodshed. Amon reigns briefly and is assassinated.
Josiah reigns and repairs the temple. The Book of the Law is found. Huldah the prophetess foretells judgment but promises Josiah mercy in his lifetime.
Josiah renews the covenant, destroys idols, and restores proper worship. Despite reforms, God decrees judgment. Josiah dies in battle at Megiddo.
Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon besieges Judah. Jehoiachin is taken captive, and Zedekiah becomes king. Babylon dominates Judah.
Jerusalem falls. The temple, palace, and city walls are destroyed. Many are exiled to Babylon. Gedaliah governs the remnant but is assassinated. Jehoiachin is later released from prison in Babylon.
Genealogies from Adam through the patriarchs, tracing humanity’s beginnings and Israel’s ancestry.
Genealogies of Judah’s descendants, including Hezron’s line leading to David.
David’s descendants are listed, including Solomon and the kings of Judah down to the exile.
Genealogies of Judah’s and Simeon’s descendants, including Jabez’s prayer to God for blessing.
Genealogies of Reuben, Gad, and half of Manasseh, noting their wars and exile for unfaithfulness.
Genealogies of Levi’s descendants, including priests, musicians, and Levitical towns.
Genealogies of Issachar, Benjamin, Naphtali, Manasseh, Ephraim, and Asher.
Genealogies of Benjamin’s descendants, highlighting Saul’s family.
Genealogies of returned exiles and Levitical gatekeepers. Saul’s genealogy repeated.
The death of Saul and his sons at Mount Gilboa; Saul’s unfaithfulness causes his downfall.
David is anointed king. He captures Jerusalem, makes it his capital, and honors his mighty men.
Warriors from many tribes join David, strengthening his kingdom.
David attempts to bring the ark to Jerusalem; Uzzah dies for touching it irreverently.
David defeats the Philistines with God’s help, affirming God’s presence with him.
David organizes the Levites and brings the ark to Jerusalem with rejoicing.
David places the ark in a tent, appoints Levites for worship, and offers a psalm of thanks.
God promises David an eternal dynasty through the prophet Nathan. David responds with humility.
David defeats surrounding nations, establishing dominion and dedicating treasures to God.
David defeats the Ammonites and Arameans after their insult to his messengers.
David’s army defeats the Ammonites and Philistine giants. Rabbah is captured.
David’s census brings God’s wrath. A plague is stopped when David builds an altar on Araunah’s threshing floor.
David prepares materials and workers for the temple, instructing Solomon to build it.
David organizes the Levites by divisions for temple service.
David organizes the priests into 24 divisions for orderly temple worship.
David organizes musicians under Asaph, Heman, and Jeduthun for temple worship.
David organizes gatekeepers, treasurers, and other temple officials.
David organizes Israel’s military, tribal leaders, officials, and royal administrators.
David publicly charges Solomon to build the temple, giving him plans and encouraging him to trust God.
David leads Israel in generous offerings for the temple. He prays a prayer of praise. Solomon is made king, and David dies after a long reign.
Solomon begins his reign, offers sacrifices at Gibeon, and asks God for wisdom. God grants him wisdom, wealth, and honor.
Solomon prepares to build the temple, securing materials and skilled workers from King Hiram of Tyre.
Solomon begins construction of the temple in Jerusalem, with detailed descriptions of its dimensions and decorations.
Temple furnishings are crafted: bronze altar, sea, lampstands, tables, courts, and vessels for worship.
The ark is brought into the temple. The glory of the Lord fills the house so the priests cannot stand to minister.
Solomon prays a dedication prayer, asking God to hear from heaven and forgive His people when they repent.
Fire comes down from heaven to consume the sacrifices. God appears to Solomon, promising blessing for obedience and exile for disobedience.
Solomon’s accomplishments: fortified cities, conscripted labor, temple service, and trade with Hiram.
The Queen of Sheba visits Solomon, marvels at his wisdom and wealth. Solomon’s greatness surpasses all kings. He dies after reigning 40 years.
Rehoboam becomes king. He rejects wise counsel, increases burdens, and Israel’s ten tribes rebel, making Jeroboam king.
Rehoboam fortifies Judah, is faithful at first, and priests and Levites migrate from Israel to Judah.
Rehoboam forsakes God, and Shishak of Egypt invades. Rehoboam humbles himself, and God spares total destruction.
Abijah reigns in Judah, defeats Jeroboam in battle by trusting God.
Asa reigns, removes idols, and experiences peace. God grants victory over a vast Cushite army.
Prophet Azariah encourages Asa to remain faithful. Asa reforms Judah, removes idols, and renews the covenant.
Asa relies on Aram instead of God against Israel. Hanani rebukes him; Asa imprisons him and later dies of disease.
Jehoshaphat reigns faithfully, strengthens Judah, and sends officials to teach God’s law throughout the land.
Jehoshaphat allies with Ahab. Micaiah prophesies Ahab’s death in battle. Ahab disguises himself but is killed.
Jehoshaphat appoints judges and exhorts them to judge faithfully, fearing God above all.
Jehoshaphat faces Moab and Ammon. He seeks God in prayer, and God miraculously defeats the enemies through confusion. Judah praises God.
Jehoram reigns wickedly in Judah, kills his brothers, and follows Ahab’s ways. He dies painfully, unloved.
Ahaziah reigns briefly and wickedly. Athaliah seizes power and kills the royal family, except Joash who is hidden.
Jehoiada the priest crowns Joash king. Athaliah is executed, and covenant worship is restored.
Joash repairs the temple under Jehoiada’s guidance, but after Jehoiada’s death he turns to idolatry and kills Jehoiada’s son. Joash is assassinated.
Amaziah reigns, initially following God but later worships Edomite idols. He is defeated by Israel and assassinated.
Uzziah reigns successfully and builds Judah’s strength. Pride leads him to usurp priestly duties; God strikes him with leprosy.
Jotham reigns faithfully, strengthens Judah, and builds cities. He prospers because he walks uprightly.
Ahaz reigns wickedly, practices idolatry, and sacrifices children. Judah suffers defeats, but prophets urge compassion on captives.
Hezekiah reigns faithfully, purifies the temple, restores worship, and leads Judah in covenant renewal.
Hezekiah invites all Israel and Judah to celebrate Passover in Jerusalem. Many respond, and the feast brings great joy.
Hezekiah organizes priests, Levites, and tithes. Worship is restored and Judah prospers.
Sennacherib of Assyria invades. Hezekiah prays, and God delivers Judah by striking down the Assyrians. Hezekiah later falls into pride but humbles himself.
Manasseh reigns wickedly, filling Jerusalem with idolatry. Later he repents in captivity, returns, and reforms. Amon reigns briefly and wickedly.
Josiah reigns faithfully, purges idolatry, and repairs the temple. The Book of the Law is found, leading to covenant renewal.
Josiah leads a great Passover celebration. Later, he dies in battle against Pharaoh Neco at Megiddo.
Judah’s last kings reign wickedly. Jerusalem is conquered by Babylon, the temple destroyed, and the people exiled. The book ends with Cyrus of Persia allowing Jews to return and rebuild.
Cyrus of Persia issues a decree allowing Jews to return to Jerusalem and rebuild the temple. Sacred vessels taken by Nebuchadnezzar are returned.
A list of exiles returning from Babylon is recorded, detailing families, priests, Levites, singers, and servants. The total is about 50,000.
The altar is rebuilt, sacrifices resume, and the Feast of Tabernacles is celebrated. The temple foundation is laid, with great rejoicing and weeping.
Enemies of Judah oppose the rebuilding, writing accusations to Persian kings. Work on the temple halts for many years due to opposition.
Prophets Haggai and Zechariah encourage the rebuilding. Tattenai, governor of Trans-Euphrates, questions the work and reports to Darius.
Darius confirms Cyrus’ decree. The temple is completed and dedicated with joy. Passover is celebrated by all who returned.
Ezra, a skilled scribe, receives royal authority from Artaxerxes to teach and enforce God’s law. He leads a new group of exiles to Jerusalem.
Ezra lists those returning with him. He proclaims a fast for safe travel. God protects them, and temple treasures are delivered safely.
Ezra learns of intermarriage with pagan nations. He prays in deep grief, confessing Israel’s sin and acknowledging God’s mercy.
The people confess their sin and agree to separate from foreign wives. A list of those guilty of intermarriage is recorded.
Nehemiah, cupbearer to the Persian king, hears of Jerusalem’s broken walls. He weeps, fasts, and prays for God’s mercy and favor.
Nehemiah receives Artaxerxes’ permission to rebuild Jerusalem’s walls. He inspects the ruins secretly and rallies the people to begin the work.
Families and groups rebuild sections of the wall, each contributing to the restoration effort with unity and diligence.
Opposition from enemies brings ridicule and threats. Nehemiah arms the workers, urging them to trust God and remain vigilant.
Nehemiah addresses internal injustice, rebuking nobles for exploiting the poor. He sets an example by serving without demanding governor’s privileges.
Enemies plot to distract and intimidate Nehemiah. He refuses their traps. The wall is completed in 52 days, and enemies lose confidence.
Nehemiah appoints leaders and records the genealogy of the first returnees under Zerubbabel to repopulate Jerusalem.
Ezra reads the Law publicly. The people weep, but Nehemiah and Ezra encourage them to rejoice. The Feast of Tabernacles is celebrated with joy.
The people confess sins and recount God’s faithfulness through history, renewing their covenant to obey His law.
Leaders and people make a written covenant, pledging to keep God’s commands, honor the Sabbath, and support the temple with tithes and offerings.
Leaders settle in Jerusalem, and others are chosen by lot to live there. Genealogies of priests, Levites, and gatekeepers are recorded.
Priests and Levites are listed. The wall’s dedication is celebrated with great rejoicing, music, and sacrifices. Worship is organized.
Nehemiah returns to find corruption: foreign influence, neglect of temple duties, Sabbath-breaking, and intermarriage. He rebukes and reforms the people, restoring covenant faithfulness.
King Xerxes holds a lavish feast. Queen Vashti refuses his command to appear, so she is deposed to set an example for all women.
Esther, a Jewish orphan raised by Mordecai, is chosen as queen. Mordecai uncovers a plot against the king and reports it.
Haman rises to power and demands honor, but Mordecai refuses to bow. Enraged, Haman plots to destroy all Jews and casts lots (Purim) to set the date.
Mordecai urges Esther to plead with the king. Esther agrees, saying, “If I perish, I perish,” and prepares to approach the king uninvited.
Esther approaches the king, who receives her favorably. She invites the king and Haman to a banquet, arousing Haman’s pride and fury toward Mordecai.
The king, unable to sleep, reads records and learns of Mordecai’s past loyalty. Haman, intending to seek Mordecai’s death, is ordered to honor him publicly instead.
At Esther’s banquet, she exposes Haman’s plot against her people. The king orders Haman to be hanged on the gallows he had prepared for Mordecai.
The king grants Esther and Mordecai authority to write a decree allowing Jews to defend themselves. Mordecai is honored, and the Jews rejoice.
The Jews defeat their enemies on the appointed day. Purim is established as an annual feast to celebrate their deliverance.
Mordecai is exalted to second in command under the king, bringing prosperity and peace to the Jews.
Job, a righteous man, is blessed with wealth and family. Satan challenges his integrity. God permits Satan to test him. Job loses possessions and children but remains faithful.
Satan is allowed to afflict Job with painful sores. Job’s wife urges him to curse God, but he refuses. Three friends—Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar—come to comfort him.
Job laments his birth, wishing he had never lived, and pours out his anguish.
Eliphaz speaks, suggesting Job’s suffering is due to hidden sin and urging him to seek God for restoration.
Eliphaz continues, emphasizing that God disciplines but also heals those who repent.
Job responds, expressing the weight of his suffering and disappointment with his friends’ lack of compassion.
Job laments life’s brevity and misery, questioning why God seems to target him.
Bildad argues that Job’s children may have sinned, and that Job should repent for God to restore him.
Job acknowledges God’s power and sovereignty but despairs of contending with Him, longing for a mediator.
Job pleads with God to explain his suffering and laments being born only to suffer.
Zophar accuses Job of great guilt and urges him to repent, promising restoration if he does.
Job responds by affirming his knowledge of God’s wisdom and power, countering his friends’ simplistic views.
Job declares his desire to argue his case before God and accuses his friends of speaking falsely for God.
Job reflects on human frailty, death, and his longing for renewal beyond the grave.
Eliphaz insists Job’s words show guilt, describing the fate of the wicked as hopeless.
Job laments his friends’ cruelty, describing himself as crushed by God, yet he hopes for a heavenly witness.
Job despairs of life, feeling mocked and abandoned, and longs for the grave as relief.
Bildad describes the terrifying fate of the wicked, implying Job fits this pattern.
Job laments abandonment by friends and family but declares faith: “I know my Redeemer lives.”
Zophar argues that the wicked prosper briefly but quickly face judgment and destruction.
Job observes that many wicked live long, prosperous lives, contradicting his friends’ claims.
Eliphaz accuses Job of oppression and great sin, urging him to repent for restoration.
Job longs to present his case before God, confident he would be vindicated, though he cannot find Him.
Job observes injustice in the world, with the wicked oppressing the poor, seemingly unpunished.
Bildad emphasizes human unworthiness before God’s greatness and holiness.
Job marvels at God’s power in creation, describing His control over the heavens and seas.
Job maintains his integrity, insisting he will not deny his righteousness, though describing the fate of the wicked.
A poem on wisdom: true wisdom is hidden from man and found only in the fear of the Lord.
Job recalls his past honor, prosperity, and respect, when God’s blessing was evident in his life.
Job laments his present humiliation and suffering, contrasting it with his former honor.
Job makes his final defense, declaring his innocence and integrity in moral, social, and spiritual matters.
Elihu, a younger man, speaks after the friends fall silent, angry at both Job and the friends’ failure.
Elihu argues that God speaks through suffering to correct and save people from pride and destruction.
Elihu defends God’s justice, insisting He cannot do wrong, and challenges Job’s claims of innocence.
Elihu argues that human sin or righteousness does not affect God’s nature but affects other people.
Elihu insists God uses suffering to teach and discipline, calling Job to humble submission.
Elihu describes God’s greatness in creation and His control over storms, preparing for God’s appearance.
God speaks from the whirlwind, questioning Job about creation to reveal His wisdom and Job’s limitations.
God continues, describing animals and nature to highlight His power and wisdom beyond human control.
God challenges Job again. Job humbles himself. God describes the behemoth as an example of His mighty creation.
God describes Leviathan’s power, emphasizing human inability and His own unmatched strength.
Job repents in humility. God rebukes Job’s friends for misrepresenting Him. Job intercedes for them, and God restores Job’s fortunes, blessing him greatly.
Anonymous (wisdom psalm). Theme: contrast of righteous and wicked. The blessed one delights in God’s law and prospers, while the wicked perish.
Davidic (royal/messianic psalm). Theme: God’s anointed King. Nations rebel, but God establishes His King; refuge in Him brings blessing.
Davidic (when fleeing Absalom). Theme: trust amid danger. Surrounded by enemies, David cries to God and rests in His sustaining protection.
Davidic. Theme: evening prayer of trust. David calls on God for deliverance, exhorts trust, and finds peace in God alone.
Davidic. Theme: morning prayer for guidance. David contrasts the wicked and the righteous, asking God to lead him in His way.
Davidic (penitential psalm). Theme: cry for mercy. David pleads for healing and deliverance, trusting God will hear and save.
Davidic (concerning Cush the Benjamite). Theme: appeal for justice. David calls on God as righteous judge against false accusations.
Davidic (hymn). Theme: God’s majesty and human dignity. Creation reveals God’s glory, and humanity is crowned with honor under Him.
Davidic. Theme: thanksgiving for God’s justice. David praises God for judging nations and delivering the oppressed.
Anonymous (lament). Theme: God’s justice for the oppressed. The psalmist laments the arrogance of the wicked and calls on God to act.
Davidic. Theme: confidence in God’s justice. Though foundations crumble, the Lord is righteous and tests both wicked and just.
Davidic. Theme: God’s faithful word. Surrounded by lies and deceit, David trusts the pure and flawless word of the Lord.
Davidic. Theme: prayer in despair. Feeling abandoned, David cries out, but ends with renewed trust in God’s steadfast love.
Davidic. Theme: human corruption. The fool denies God, all are corrupt, but God is with the righteous generation.
Davidic. Theme: who may dwell with God. A description of the righteous life: blamelessness, truthfulness, and integrity.
Davidic (Miktam). Theme: God as refuge. David delights in God’s presence, confident in His eternal security and hope.
Davidic (prayer). Theme: plea for vindication. David calls on God to examine his heart and protect him from violent enemies.
Davidic (royal thanksgiving). Theme: God’s deliverance. David praises God for rescuing him from enemies, exalting His power and faithfulness.
Davidic. Theme: God’s revelation. The heavens declare God’s glory, and His law is perfect, reviving the soul.
Davidic (royal psalm). Theme: prayer for victory. The people pray for the king’s success, trusting God over human power.
Davidic (royal psalm). Theme: thanksgiving for victory. David rejoices in God’s strength and salvation; the king’s enemies will be destroyed.
Davidic (lament/messianic). Theme: suffering and deliverance. David cries of forsakenness, yet trusts God; prophecy fulfilled in Christ’s crucifixion.
Davidic (shepherd psalm). Theme: God as shepherd. The Lord provides, guides, protects, and restores, giving eternal security.
Davidic. Theme: the King of glory. God owns the earth; only the pure may ascend His hill. The King of glory enters triumphantly.
Davidic (acrostic prayer). Theme: trust and guidance. David pleads for forgiveness, guidance, and deliverance from enemies.
Davidic. Theme: integrity before God. David appeals for vindication, walking blamelessly and loving God’s house.
Davidic. Theme: trust in God’s presence. The Lord is my light and salvation; David longs to dwell in God’s house and seeks His help.
Davidic. Theme: prayer for deliverance. David pleads not to be dragged with the wicked; he praises God for hearing his cry.
Davidic (hymn). Theme: the voice of the Lord. God’s voice thunders over creation; He reigns as King, giving peace to His people.
Davidic (song for temple dedication). Theme: thanksgiving for deliverance. Mourning turns to dancing as God rescues from death.
Davidic. Theme: refuge in God. In distress, David entrusts his spirit to God, praising His steadfast love.
Davidic (penitential psalm). Theme: blessing of forgiveness. Confession brings relief; God forgives and surrounds with steadfast love.
Anonymous (hymn). Theme: praise of God’s sovereignty. God’s word is upright, His plans stand forever, and He cares for His people.
Davidic (when feigning madness before Abimelek). Theme: God delivers the righteous. David calls to taste and see God’s goodness.
Davidic. Theme: plea for vindication. David asks God to contend with those who attack him, rejoicing when the Lord rescues.
Davidic. Theme: contrast of wickedness and God’s love. The wicked plot evil, but God’s steadfast love reaches the heavens.
Davidic (wisdom psalm). Theme: trust vs. fretting. The wicked wither, but the righteous inherit the land and know God’s peace.
Davidic (penitential psalm). Theme: cry under discipline. David confesses sin, laments suffering, and seeks God’s salvation.
Davidic. Theme: life’s brevity. David reflects on human frailty, pleading for deliverance and hope in God.
Davidic. Theme: thanksgiving and petition. David praises God’s past deliverance, declares His works, and prays for present help.
Davidic. Theme: blessed are those who consider the poor. David prays for healing, laments betrayal by a close friend, and affirms God’s sustaining presence.
Sons of Korah (lament). Theme: longing for God. As a deer pants for water, so the psalmist thirsts for God amid despair and exile.
Anonymous (linked to Psalm 42, likely Korahite). Theme: prayer for vindication. The psalmist pleads for God’s light and truth to lead him back to His altar.
Sons of Korah (communal lament). Theme: appeal for God’s help. Despite faithfulness, Israel suffers defeat and pleads for deliverance.
Sons of Korah (royal/wedding psalm). Theme: the king’s majesty and the bride’s beauty, foreshadowing Christ the Bridegroom.
Sons of Korah. Theme: God our refuge. Though nations rage and the earth shakes, God is present and exalted among the nations.
Sons of Korah. Theme: God the King of all nations. A call to clap and shout in triumph, for God reigns over the earth.
Sons of Korah (hymn). Theme: Zion, the city of God. God’s greatness and protection are celebrated in His holy city.
Sons of Korah (wisdom psalm). Theme: the futility of wealth. Rich and poor alike face death, but God redeems the faithful.
Asaph. Theme: true worship. God summons the earth, condemning empty ritual and demanding obedience and thanksgiving.
Davidic (after sin with Bathsheba). Theme: repentance. David confesses sin, asks for a clean heart, and pleads for renewed joy in God’s salvation.
Davidic (when Doeg betrayed him). Theme: God’s judgment on the deceitful. The wicked trust in riches, but the righteous trust in God’s steadfast love.
Davidic. Theme: human corruption. The fool denies God; all are corrupt, but God saves His people.
Davidic (when Ziphites betrayed him). Theme: prayer for deliverance. David trusts God to repay his enemies and uphold him.
Davidic. Theme: betrayal’s pain. David laments treachery by a close companion but casts his burden on the Lord.
Davidic (when seized by Philistines in Gath). Theme: trust amid fear. When afraid, David trusts God, who delivers him from death.
Davidic (when fleeing Saul in a cave). Theme: refuge in God. Amid danger, David sings praise for God’s steadfast love and faithfulness.
Davidic. Theme: condemnation of unjust rulers. The wicked are likened to venomous snakes, but the righteous rejoice at God’s judgment.
Davidic (when Saul sent men to watch his house). Theme: deliverance from enemies. David prays for protection and praises God as fortress.
Davidic (after battle with Aram and Edom). Theme: national lament and hope. Israel cries for restoration, but God promises victory.
Davidic. Theme: prayer for refuge. From the ends of the earth David cries to God, asking to be led to the rock higher than himself and to dwell in God’s presence forever.
Davidic. Theme: trust in God alone. Salvation, honor, and refuge are found in God, not in wealth or human strength.
Davidic (when in the wilderness of Judah). Theme: longing for God’s presence. David thirsts for God, praising Him even in dry and weary places.
Davidic. Theme: deliverance from secret plots. David laments the schemes of the wicked, but God will strike them down.
Davidic (song of praise). Theme: God’s abundant provision. The psalm celebrates God’s forgiveness, power over creation, and blessing of the earth.
Anonymous (hymn). Theme: praise for God’s mighty deeds. The psalmist recalls God’s works in Israel’s history and personal deliverance.
Anonymous (song). Theme: God’s blessing for the nations. A prayer that God’s face shine on His people so all nations may know His salvation.
Davidic. Theme: God as victorious warrior. God scatters His enemies, cares for the fatherless, and dwells in Zion amid triumph.
Davidic (lament/messianic). Theme: suffering servant. David cries out in deep distress, foreshadowing Christ’s passion.
Davidic. Theme: urgent plea for help. A short psalm asking God to deliver quickly from adversaries.
Anonymous (likely elderly psalmist). Theme: lifelong trust. From youth to old age, the psalmist declares God’s faithfulness and seeks continued deliverance.
Solomonic (or for Solomon). Theme: the ideal king. A prayer for righteous rule, justice for the poor, and worldwide dominion; foreshadows Christ.
Asaph (wisdom psalm). Theme: struggle with the prosperity of the wicked. The psalmist finds resolution in God’s presence and eternal justice.
Asaph. Theme: lament over destruction. The psalmist cries to God after the sanctuary is defiled, pleading for deliverance from enemies.
Asaph. Theme: God the righteous judge. The psalm declares that exaltation comes from God, who will bring down the wicked.
Asaph. Theme: God’s awe-inspiring power. God is praised for His victory over enemies, instilling fear among the nations.
Asaph. Theme: remembering God’s deeds. In trouble, the psalmist recalls God’s wonders, especially the exodus, as grounds for hope.
Asaph (historical psalm). Theme: Israel’s repeated rebellion. The psalm recounts God’s faithfulness and Israel’s failures, urging future generations to trust Him.
Asaph (communal lament). Theme: plea after destruction. The psalmist cries out as Jerusalem lies in ruins, asking God for mercy and justice.
Asaph. Theme: prayer for restoration. God is addressed as the Shepherd of Israel, asked to shine His face and save His people.
Asaph. Theme: call to covenant faithfulness. God recalls His deliverance of Israel, urges obedience, and laments their stubbornness.
Asaph. Theme: God the supreme Judge. God rebukes unjust earthly rulers, declaring His authority over all nations.
Asaph. Theme: prayer against hostile nations. The psalmist pleads with God to defeat conspiring enemies and show His supremacy.
Sons of Korah. Theme: longing for God’s dwelling. Blessed are those who live in God’s house and find strength in His presence.
Sons of Korah. Theme: plea for restoration. The psalm recalls past deliverance, prays for revival, and trusts in God’s steadfast love.
Davidic. Theme: prayer for mercy and help. David cries out for God’s grace and affirms His greatness among the nations.
Sons of Korah. Theme: Zion, the city of God. Nations are counted as born in Zion, showing God’s universal plan of redemption.
Sons of Korah (Heman the Ezrahite). Theme: darkest lament. The psalmist cries out from deep suffering, feeling abandoned by God.
Ethan the Ezrahite. Theme: God’s covenant with David. The psalm praises God’s faithfulness but laments apparent rejection of the king.
Moses. Theme: God’s eternity and human frailty. Life is short under God’s wrath, so the psalmist asks God to teach us to number our days.
Anonymous. Theme: God our refuge. Those who dwell in His shelter are protected; He delivers from fear, plague, and danger.
Anonymous (Sabbath psalm). Theme: praise for God’s works. The righteous flourish like palm trees while the wicked perish.
Anonymous. Theme: God reigns in majesty. The Lord is enthroned, mightier than the seas, and His decrees stand firm.
Anonymous. Theme: plea for justice. The psalmist asks God to punish the arrogant and affirms His discipline brings blessing.
Anonymous. Theme: call to worship and obedience. God is the great King; Israel is warned not to harden their hearts like in the wilderness.
Anonymous. Theme: God’s reign proclaimed to the nations. A new song celebrates His glory and coming judgment with equity.
Anonymous. Theme: the Lord reigns. Fire and lightning reveal His glory, idols are shamed, and the righteous rejoice in Him.
Anonymous. Theme: joy in God’s salvation. Sing to the Lord for His marvelous deeds; He will judge the world with righteousness.
Anonymous. Theme: the holy King. God reigns over nations in justice, exalted in Zion, worthy of worship.
Anonymous (thanksgiving psalm). Theme: call to joyful worship. All lands are summoned to serve the Lord with gladness, for His steadfast love endures forever.
Davidic. Theme: commitment to integrity. David vows to live blamelessly, reject wickedness, and rule justly in his house.
Anonymous (penitential/lament). Theme: prayer of the afflicted. The psalmist laments personal and national suffering, yet affirms God’s eternal reign and future restoration of Zion.
Davidic. Theme: praise for God’s mercy. Bless the Lord, who forgives, heals, redeems, and shows steadfast love from everlasting to everlasting.
Anonymous (hymn). Theme: God the Creator and Sustainer. The psalm celebrates God’s majesty, creation’s order, and His providential care for all creatures.
Anonymous (historical psalm). Theme: God’s covenant faithfulness. Recounts God’s deeds from Abraham through the exodus and settlement in Canaan.
Anonymous. Theme: Israel’s unfaithfulness. The psalm confesses sins throughout Israel’s history, yet affirms God’s steadfast love and plea for deliverance.
Anonymous. Theme: thanksgiving for deliverance. God rescues people from distress—wanderers, prisoners, the sick, and sailors—showing His steadfast love.
Davidic (combination of Psalms 57 & 60). Theme: confidence in victory. David praises God and calls for His help over nations.
Davidic (lament). Theme: plea against false accusers. David calls for judgment on his enemies but ends affirming God as his deliverer.
Davidic (royal/messianic psalm). Theme: the Lord’s anointed king and priest. The Messiah reigns at God’s right hand as priest forever.
Anonymous. Theme: praise for God’s works. His deeds are majestic, His covenant remembered, and His precepts trustworthy.
Anonymous (wisdom psalm). Theme: blessings of the righteous. Those who fear the Lord are steadfast, generous, and remembered forever.
Anonymous (Hallel psalm). Theme: praise to the exalted Lord. God raises the poor and needy, showing His greatness.
Anonymous (Hallel psalm). Theme: God’s power at the exodus. The sea fled and mountains trembled at His presence.
Anonymous (Hallel psalm). Theme: God vs. idols. Unlike powerless idols, the Lord blesses those who trust Him.
Anonymous (Hallel psalm). Theme: thanksgiving for deliverance. The psalmist loves the Lord who heard his cry and vows to call on Him forever.
Anonymous (shortest psalm). Theme: universal praise. All nations are called to glorify God for His steadfast love.
Anonymous (Hallel psalm). Theme: thanksgiving for God’s salvation. The rejected stone becomes the cornerstone; His love endures forever.
Anonymous (acrostic psalm). Theme: delight in God’s law. The longest psalm exalts God’s word as life-giving, guiding, and sustaining.
Anonymous (Song of Ascents). Theme: prayer for deliverance. The psalmist, living among deceitful people, calls on the Lord for peace.
Anonymous (Song of Ascents). Theme: God our keeper. The psalmist lifts eyes to the hills, affirming help comes from the Lord, who guards His people day and night.
Davidic (Song of Ascents). Theme: joy in Jerusalem. The psalmist rejoices in going to God’s house and prays for the peace of Jerusalem.
Anonymous (Song of Ascents). Theme: plea for mercy. The psalmist looks to God’s hand like a servant to a master, asking for mercy amid scorn.
Davidic (Song of Ascents). Theme: God our deliverer. If the Lord had not been on Israel’s side, enemies would have swallowed them alive.
Anonymous (Song of Ascents). Theme: security in God. Those who trust the Lord are like Mount Zion, unshakable and enduring forever.
Anonymous (Song of Ascents). Theme: restoration joy. The psalm recalls God’s past restoration and prays for renewed blessing, with weeping turning into joy.
Solomonic (Song of Ascents). Theme: God builds and sustains. Labor, security, and family prosper only by God’s blessing.
Anonymous (Song of Ascents). Theme: blessings of fearing God. Those who walk in His ways enjoy fruitful family life and peace in Israel.
Anonymous (Song of Ascents). Theme: perseverance amid affliction. Though afflicted from youth, Israel affirms the Lord’s justice against oppressors.
