Before the seventh seal, 144,000 servants of God are sealed from the twelve tribes of Israel, and John sees a great multitude from every nation worshiping before the throne having come out of great tribulation.

The seventh seal brings silence in heaven, then seven angels with trumpets begin God's judgments on earth through hail, fire, a burning mountain, a fallen star, and darkness covering a third of creation.

The fifth and sixth trumpets release demonic locusts from the abyss to torment unrepentant humanity, followed by a massive army of 200 million horsemen killing a third of mankind, yet people still refuse to repent.

A mighty angel holding a little scroll declares that in the days of the seventh trumpet, God's mystery will be completed, and John is commanded to eat the scroll which is sweet in his mouth but bitter in his stomach.

John measures the temple while two witnesses prophesy for 1,260 days with great power until they are killed and resurrected; the seventh trumpet sounds, announcing Christ's eternal kingdom and God's wrath.

A woman clothed with the sun gives birth to a male child who will rule the nations, while a great red dragon seeks to devour the child; war breaks out in heaven, and Satan is cast down to earth with great fury.
Two beasts emerge—one from the sea with authority over all nations, and one from the earth performing signs to deceive people into worshiping the first beast and receiving its mark, 666.

The Lamb stands with 144,000 on Mount Zion singing a new song; three angels proclaim the eternal gospel, announce Babylon's fall, and warn against receiving the beast's mark before the harvest of the earth.

Seven angels prepare to pour out the seven last plagues containing God's completed wrath, while those who conquered the beast sing the song of Moses and the Lamb beside a sea of glass mixed with fire.
The seven bowls of God's wrath are poured out, bringing painful sores, death in the seas and rivers, scorching heat, darkness on the beast's kingdom, and the great earthquake at Armageddon.
John sees the judgment of the great prostitute Babylon who sits on many waters, drunk with the blood of saints, riding a scarlet beast with seven heads representing kings and kingdoms.

Babylon the great falls suddenly and completely, bringing mourning to kings, merchants, and sailors who profited from her luxury, while heaven rejoices over God's righteous judgment of her corruption.

Heaven celebrates with hallelujah choruses for God's judgment and the marriage supper of the Lamb; Christ returns as King of Kings and Lord of Lords to defeat the beast and false prophet at Armageddon.
Satan is bound for 1,000 years while martyrs reign with Christ; after his release and final rebellion, Satan is cast into the lake of fire, and all the dead face the great white throne judgment.
God creates new heavens and a new earth with the New Jerusalem descending as a bride; He dwells with His people, wiping away all tears, pain, and death in the eternal city of perfect glory.

The angel shows John the river of life and tree of life in the New Jerusalem; Jesus declares His soon coming and invites all who thirst to take the water of life freely as the Spirit and bride say 'Come.'

categories.name: Law (Torah)
categories.description: Genesis through Deuteronomy: creation, covenant, and the formation of Israel.

categories.name: History
categories.description: Joshua through Esther: conquest, kingdom, exile, and return.

categories.name: Poetry & Writings
categories.description: Job through Song of Songs: wisdom, worship, and reflections.

categories.name: Major Prophets
categories.description: Isaiah through Daniel: large prophetic works addressing judgment and hope.

categories.name: Minor Prophets
categories.description: Hosea through Malachi: shorter prophetic books with powerful messages.

categories.name: Gospels
categories.description: Matthew, Mark, Luke, John: the life, death, and resurrection of Jesus.

categories.name: Acts
categories.description: The birth and expansion of the early Church.

categories.name: Pauline Epistles
categories.description: Letters attributed to Paul addressing doctrine and church life.

categories.name: General Epistles
categories.description: Letters by other apostles and leaders to the wider church.

categories.name: Apocalypse
categories.description: Revelation: apocalyptic prophecy and ultimate hope.

entities.searchText: jesus of nazareth person messiah davidic and abrahamic heir, true israel in one person. matthew stresses fulfillment: virgin conception (isa 7:14), bethlehem birth (mic 5:2), exodus recapitulation (hos 11:1), temptation victory, authoritative torah fulfillment (5:17–20), suffering servant and risen lord.

entities.name: God (YHWH)
entities.blurb: God—the covenant name often rendered YHWH—is the Creator and Lord of history. Genesis portrays God as personal (speaking, blessing, judging), sovereign over chaos, and faithful to His promises. He for
entities.searchText: god (yhwh) divine narrative god—the covenant name often rendered yhwh—is the creator and lord of history. genesis portrays god as personal (speaking, blessing, judging), sovereign over chaos, and faithful to his promises. he forms humanity in his image (gen 1:26–27), enters into relationship with them, and, after the fall, pursues them with mercy. jewish tradition emphasizes god’s covenantal chesed (steadfast love) and justice; christian theology sees in genesis the roots of redemption that culminate in christ. from eden to babel, god’s actions frame the story: creation, judgment (flood, dispersion), and gracious election. d.god-yhwh--34eab3d9

entities.name: Moses
entities.blurb: Rescued from the Nile by Pharaoh’s daughter, raised in the court, then exiled to Midian after defending a Hebrew. At the burning bush he meets the God of the fathers; reluctant yet called, he confront
entities.searchText: moses person narrative rescued from the nile by pharaoh’s daughter, raised in the court, then exiled to midian after defending a hebrew. at the burning bush he meets the god of the fathers; reluctant yet called, he confronts pharaoh with signs and speeches, leads through the plagues, and brings israel to the sea. moses’ story in these chapters showcases divine compassion, judgment, and the birth of a nation.

entities.name: Edom’s ruins/desolation

entities.name: Ekron

entities.name: Election and herem (ban) against Canaanite idolatry

entities.name: Eleventh year, first month (fall of Tyre)

entities.name: Eleventh year, seventh month (oracle vs Egypt)

entities.name: Elihu’s four speeches

entities.name: Eliphaz’s first speech & Job’s reply

entities.name: Eliphaz’s second; Bildad’s second; Zophar’s second

entities.name: Eliphaz’s third; Bildad’s third; Zophar silent

entities.name: En-gedi; robe-cutting mercy

entities.name: Ezra 5–6 coordination
entities.blurb: Imperial verification and decrees align with prophetic impetus to complete the Temple.
entities.searchText: ezra 5–6 coordination entity historical-link imperial verification and decrees align with prophetic impetus to complete the temple.

entities.name: Ezra reads the Law at the Water Gate
entities.blurb: Public exegesis with sense given—word understood in the assembly births obedience.
entities.searchText: ezra reads the law at the water gate entity worship public exegesis with sense given—word understood in the assembly births obedience.

entities.name: Ezra’s posture: torn garments, hair pulled, prayer
entities.blurb: Priestly solidarity: confessional prayer rehearses history, grace, and the danger of repeating exile—shame becomes intercession.
entities.searchText: ezra’s posture: torn garments, hair pulled, prayer entity spirituality priestly solidarity: confessional prayer rehearses history, grace, and the danger of repeating exile—shame becomes intercession.

entities.name: Faithfulness to Jacob, steadfast love to Abraham
entities.blurb: Covenant continuity—promises to patriarchs underwrite restoration.
entities.searchText: faithfulness to jacob, steadfast love to abraham entity covenant covenant continuity—promises to patriarchs underwrite restoration.

entities.name: Fall of Babylon (Jeremiah)
entities.blurb: Comprehensive takedown of the proud empire—idols exposed, captives recalled; scroll sunk in Euphrates seals the word.
entities.searchText: fall of babylon (jeremiah) entity judgment comprehensive takedown of the proud empire—idols exposed, captives recalled; scroll sunk in euphrates seals the word.

entities.name: Family feasting cycle & Job’s priestly intercession
entities.blurb: Sons host rotating banquets; Job rises early to offer burnt offerings ‘perhaps my children have sinned’—intercession anchors festivity.
entities.searchText: family feasting cycle & job’s priestly intercession entity worship sons host rotating banquets; job rises early to offer burnt offerings ‘perhaps my children have sinned’—intercession anchors festivity.

entities.name: Famine of hearing the words of the LORD
entities.blurb: Judgment by silence—spiritual drought worse than crop failure.
entities.searchText: famine of hearing the words of the lord entity judgment judgment by silence—spiritual drought worse than crop failure.

entities.name: Fast at the Ahava canal
entities.blurb: Public dependence before peril: they seek safe travel without a military escort—faith chooses vulnerability over optics.
entities.searchText: fast at the ahava canal entity spirituality public dependence before peril: they seek safe travel without a military escort—faith chooses vulnerability over optics.

entities.name: Fast: consecrate a fast, call a sacred assembly
entities.blurb: Fasting becomes national therapy—lean bodies saying what words cannot.

entities.name: Fast days set
entities.blurb: Fourth, fifth, seventh, tenth months marked for mourning in exile.
entities.searchText: fast days set entity calendar fourth, fifth, seventh, tenth months marked for mourning in exile.

entities.name: Fasting to feasting (8:19)
entities.blurb: Ritual mourning transfigured by ethical renewal and communal joy.
entities.searchText: fasting to feasting (8:19) entity liturgical-theology ritual mourning transfigured by ethical renewal and communal joy.

entities.name: Father and son go in to the same girl

entities.name: Father-son metaphor
entities.blurb: God as nurturing father, wrestling with compassion.
entities.searchText: father-son metaphor entity metaphor god as nurturing father, wrestling with compassion.
